utterances: So this is better, a little better than domestic partnership, but it is not full marriage equality.
However, it will give us some more protections that we did not have.
And that was the goal of the lawsuit, that was what we have given four and a half years of our life to - working for.
You know, trying to protect each other, trying to help couples who have accumulated, you know, things in their life, properties, material things, emotional things.
You know, trying to help us protect each other as best we could.
Let me interrupt you…
Yeah.
…just because we only have a few seconds left.
Okay.
So, just tell me, what are your plans to celebrate this weekend?
Well, this weekend, we're going to have a civil union ceremony at our home.
Our pastor, Janice Jackson(ph), is going to officiate.
And we're going to have some of our close friends witness the ceremony.
And then, after that, we're going to go to a wonderful restaurant down in the Ironbound section of Newark and do what we love to do, which is eat and have a good time.
Well, my congratulations to you.
Thank you very much.
Saundra Toby-Heath and Alicia Heath-Toby, thanks so much for talking with us today.
You have a blessed day.
We are watching yet another hurricane.
This time, its name is Michael, and it is headed directly for the Florida Panhandle.
That's where it's expected to make landfall later today.
The hurricane intensified overnight.
It is now a Category 4 storm.
Here's Florida Governor Rick Scott yesterday.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
This storm is deadly.
Do not take a chance.
Think about the destruction we've seen before with storms like Hurricane Irma.
The Panhandle and Big Bend will likely see winds in excess of 110 miles per hour.
Stop to think about that, 110-miles-per-hour winds.
Today, winds are clocking in at around 145 miles per hour.
NPR's Greg Allen is following the storm from Tallahassee and joins us now.
Greg, what does it look like out the window where you are?
Well, it's remarkably calm here still.
The storm is this monster right offshore.
But we're just starting to feel the outer bands, you know, a little wind, a little rain.
But even in the - right at the coast, in Panama City and areas like that, where it's close to where it's going to make landfall, they're just starting to get the outer bands.
But it's a fast-moving storm.
We should be seeing it here by this afternoon.
Here in Tallahassee, the main concern is all the trees we have here, which are these big live oak trees with Spanish moss festooned on them.
Those trees can be very susceptible to wind damage.

And if we get these hurricane-force or tropical-storm-force winds, even - 'cause we're a bit farther from where the eye's expected to be - that's likely to bring down some of those trees and cause extensive power outages.
So we heard the governor there saying, people, you've got to leave.
Don't take anything for granted.
Are people heeding that message?
Are people out?
You know, I think so.
It's hard to, you know, to judge.
But, you know, hundreds of thousands of people are under voluntary or mandatory evacuation orders here.
The most concerns are along the Panhandle coastal communities - Bay County, Franklin County, Gulf County, those areas.
And those are not really populated counties.
There's a lot of visitors there for resorts, for beach areas.
And so I think the sense is there's really very little reason for people to have stayed.
And in Bay County, at least one shelter is full, so we know that some people are taking heed.
We're starting to see some storm surge - storm surge flooding already in areas like Apalachicola and Cedar Key, some of these low-lying fishing communities right on the beach.
And so, you know, the roads are going to be - going to be blocked fairly soon in some of these areas.
So if people haven't gotten out, the time is running out.
I mean, we should always be careful of using superlatives when talking about big weather events, but a lot of people are calling this historic.
It is a Cat 4 now - Category 4.
Has the Florida Panhandle ever seen anything like this?
The bank blew past its goal of eliminating half of its voice mail boxes and to date has eliminated about two-thirds.
Across the whole bank so far, that's over $8 million in annual savings.
Coca-Cola recently made a similar move, and only 6 percent of employees chose to keep voice mail.
Voice mail, like the pay phone and pager before it, is on its way out.
Sean Hakl is head of new products for Verizon's business division.
Before the digital era, he says more than 80 percent of business lines had voice mail.
Now, he estimates only a third of office phones have it.
No.
I was the first reporter in recent years and, to my knowledge, the last that he had kind of allowed inside his circle.
I went to church with Tom.
I spent time with his wife and his daughter.
He's very, very much involved in the Baptist Church in Texas.
He teaches Sunday school class.
He has a men's group there that he goes to or was going to virtually every week.
He goes home to his district quite often.
And his church and his belief in Jesus are really very, very central to who he is as a person.
And very central to his politics as well.
Extremely so.
He basically believes that America needs to be a more God-centered nation.
He believes that the Constitution was inspired by God.
And he believes that his mission as a politician is to bring America more around to an agenda that is an agenda that would be that of Jesus Christ.

And when I said to him that many people would be quite upset at his view on the separation of church and state and would not be very pleased with having leaders who have these kind of views, he said to me, `When faced with the truth, the truth hurts.
It's human nature not to face that.
People hate the messenger, and that's why they killed Christ.
And this was his explanation of why he truly believed that he had the answers for America and that people ought to go along with it.
And again, although certainly this is something pretty well-known about him, it isn't--I don't think he has particularly worn his religion on his sleeve, so to speak.
No.
He's really toned it down.
He's toned it down dramatically, and many of the most revealing things about Tom are in his speeches to the Christian Coalition and in some of his discussions with me.
And it was a side of him that I personally found to be rather extreme and it's a side of him that he does not allow to be out in public all that much.
And after you wrote that article, was he upset that you had talked about it as much as you had or you said he didn't--you said it was the last time that he had been that forthcoming in an interview.
Did he react negatively to the profile or...
Yes, he did.
I never heard from him directly, but indirectly, I heard that he was very upset about the story.
Now Tom DeLay is known to be a very effective fund-raiser for the Republican Party.
How do you account for that?
What is it about him that makes him so good at that?
He's a bulldog of a guy.
Tom is a very small person physically.
That's one of the things that struck me when I first met him.
This is a fellow who's 5'7"", and when he was in high school, he was a 140-pound offensive tackle on the football team, which gives you an idea of the kind of stick-to-itiveness that he had.
I mean, he's a ferocious competitor and always has been, and I think part of that comes out of a tough family background.

As far as the fund-raising goes, he was early on one of the people to really adapt to the new rules of the game politically in terms of the importance of money and the way he was able to funnel it to other candidates, not only to assure his own political future, but also to become a force within the Republican Party by becoming known as the guy who could deliver money to people throughout the Republican caucus.
Let's see if we can get a call in here quickly.
Scott in Ft.
Lauderdale, Florida.
Scott, go ahead.
Good afternoon.
Part A and Part B.
Part A would be how'd he got from pest control and extermination to Congress?
And Part B is where does he see himself going after Congress?
OK.
Thanks for those two questions.
We're going to try and answer them quickly for you, Scott.
Thank you very much.
Pest control to Congress is really pretty fascinating.
This is in the Ronald Reagan era.
As a small businessman, Tom DeLay developed a ferocious hatred for the Environmental Protection Agency.
He wanted to use stronger chemicals in his pest control business, and here he was being stopped by an agency that he called the Gestapo of government.

And Tom DeLay, as originally part of the Reagan revolution, got elected to the Legislature in Texas on a pro-business agenda and was in the minority, felt very much like an oppressed minority as a Republican then in Texas and worked hard to climb in the Texas Legislature and then make the leap to Congress.
Since then, he's used his fund-raising skills and his people skills to become what--the guy they now call the Hammer and the Whip to whip his party in line.
All right.
Peter Perl, thanks so much for joining us today.
Thank you.
Peter Perl is a writer and editor with The Washington Post Magazine.
He joined us from The Washington Post studios.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington.
When voice mail was developed in the late 1970s, it quickly became an essential tool for businesses, but in the past few years it has been in decline.
And as NPR's Yuki Noguchi reports, some offices have opted to hang up on it altogether.
After JPMorgan Chase said last week it was canceling voice mail for most of its employees, I sent their public relations department an email.
A bit later, there was that familiar red light on my desk phone.
(SOUNDBITE OF VOICE MAIL)
Hi, Yuki, this is Trish Wexler at Chase.
Ironically, I'm leaving you a voice mail about your email about the death of voice mail.
Wexler says the bank's chief financial officer was searching for budget cuts that wouldn't hurt too much.
Limo services was one.
Voice mail, it turned out, cost $10 per person per month and, intuitively, it seemed right for the chopping block.
You didn't even need a survey because that's how the world is changing these days.
So in January, JPMorgan offered employees who didn't need voice mail to interact with clients a choice to ditch it.
People started raising their hands.
They started volunteering - please take my voice mail away.
It's annoying.
It's redundant.
I never use it anymore.
Dr.
Christopher, you know, Dr. Puckrein is calling this a mixed bag.
How do you take a look at this at how it's going to ultimately affect consumers?
Oh, I think he's right.
It is a mixed bag.

The African-American response to pharmaceuticals is different, it is unique, particularly in relationship to inflammatory processes, which tend to under (unintelligible) or be involved with many of the chronic diseases from which we suffer a disproportionate burden.
